discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. You would need to specify tkg in the command. Look at the question.

Selected Answer: C
I'm guessing C. 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/8.0/vsphere-with-tanzu-tkg/GUID-1841861D-2401-48E8-8A16-3C428A5BAC83.html

A. kubectl show tkc dev-cluster - No - "Show" is not a kubectl command
B. kubectl get cluster dev-cluster - No - The question specifically mentions it is a Tanzu Kubernetes cluster
C. kubectl get tkc dev-cluster - Yes, this is the correct syntax
D. kubectl list cluster dev-cluster - No, "List" is not a kubectl command

C kubectl get tkc dev-cluster
kubectl get tkc

questions.question_text:
A development team has submitted a YAML specification to create a Tanzu Kubernetes cluster called dev-cluster and wants to verify that the cluster is running.

Which command should be run to obtain this verification?
How are updates applied to Tanzu Kubernetes clusters?

choices.D: A new cluster is completely configured and runs in parallel to the primary cluster prior to switchover.
choices.C: New nodes are incrementally added with new Kubernetes versions so as a new node is added, an older node is removed.
choices.A: The cluster is shutdown, Update Manager applies patches to VMs, and the cluster is restarted.
choices.B: Worker nodes are shutdown while Controllers are patched and restarted after the update.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. This is the proof they are wrong about the previous time they ask this question.

Selected Answer: C
I'll go with C, it's the Kubernetes way of things. It's a good approach as it maintains uptime and service availability.

questions.question_text: Which kubectl command is used to deploy the application when using a Kubernetes deployment specification file, my-app.yaml?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
It's B. 

Always look for the -F parameter with these questions (the filename parameter). VMware seem to omit this in the "wrong" answers.

Selected Answer: A
I'll go with "A", here's why: 

A. Assign a VM Storage Policy - Yes, this will work
B. Assign permissions to users - Not storage related!
C. Define resource limits - Resource limits usually refer to CPU and RAM. Also, how does this assign anything?
D. Add a content library - No, this is for storing images.

questions.question_text: Which step is necessary in order to allocate storage to a newly created namespace?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Docs referred for answer A:
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-EC76B511-8DEB-4595-9DFA-3E9567C98ECA.html

I'll go with "A", "docker tag".

When handling image pushing, this is about the only thing that gets done with docker instead of kubectl. 

"docker label" is not a command, so we disregard that. 

The syntax in the command shown in answer "A" is good syntax and will apply a label.

questions.question_text:
An administrator needs to label and push an image into Harbor.

Which command should the administrator run first?
